p.s: Being one of the greatest playwrights and poets back in his days, the 16th century, William Shakespeare managed to stay relevant, even get more relevant than in his lifetime after his death till today.
Numerous critics say that Shakespeare's works lost relevance and that they are outdated and too old.
That the language is not fitting for today and that they are soon to be forgotten.
ThereTheir thoughts are legitimate, with Shakespeare's works being more than 400 years old, but they are still wrong.
Till today no poet has accomplished, what Shakespeare accomplished.
Scientists and academics are in awe how just one poet could produce 38 plays and 154 Sonnetssonnets, with almost every single one of them having some sort of relevance in world history.
Furthermore Shakespeare's works are taught in the schools of almost every country and have been tranlatedtranslated to over one hundred different languages.
Without Shakespeare the poets these very critics would describe as relevant for today would not even exist.
Without Shakespeare poetry and song texts would not be the same as they are now.

Even if the original works of Shakespeare are played less frequently today countless modernizations and adaptations exist, for example Westside Story or Titanic wichwhich both are closely orientated towards Romeo and Juliet and count as classics today.
In addition even theatres, schools and universities are named after William Shakespeare because of his importance for the academic world.
And Shakespeare still being the most relevant poet or writes, 400 years after his death has one reason: his works are timeless, they can notcannot become outdated.
No other writer managed to display human emotion as good as Shakespeare.
Shakespeare lets his audience experience the raw emotions of hate, sadness happiness and, of course, love in a purity and genuinity no one other does.
The, one of a kind, gift to be able to describe human emotion, for what it really is.
And as long as there is no one who manages to beat Shakespeare in his own expertise, and as long as humans are able to watch, read and especially feel, Shakespeare will continue to stay nr.
